newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia inflation expectations inch up from lows.
newsitem.headline: Australia inflation expectations inch up from lows.

text.p: Australian consumers' inflationary expectations nudged up to 3.3 percent in July from a record low of 3.2 percent in June, the Melbourne Institute said on Thursday.
Over the past 12 months, median expectations had come down 1.0 percentage point and were still close to all time lows despite the small increase, the Institute said.
"Over the past five years, expectations have hovered around 4.0 percent," it said ."However, the past nine months has seen a significant downward shift with expectations now close to 3.5 percent."
On wage expectations, the survey found the majority of employees, 53 percent, expect no change in hourly wages received over the next 12 months, the Institute said.
This resulted in a median expectations close to zero, although on average terms employees looked for a 2.9 percent rise in wages over the period.
The survey also found a majority, 50 percent, reported no change in actual wages over the past year agains producing a median close to zero.
Averaging produced a rise of 3.0 percent for the year with a wide discrepancy between the low and high paid.
The Institute said households with an annual income of less than A$20,000 reported a 4.4 percent fall in wages while those earnings more than A$71,000 reported an increase of 5.5 percent.
"Should this trend continue, it may provide some evidence of a further widening of the income gap between the lowest and highest paid workers," it said.
March quarter data showed that the consumer price index rose 1.3 percent over the past year.
